story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Mum was diagnosed early November with a large inoperable brain tumour. As you can imagine it was a very big shock for us as it was something we never expected. We didn't know how much time we had but decided we would take every day as it comes....we had the most wonderful Christmas together and made some lovely memories. Mums Macmillan nurse Helen came weekly to visit her, she was at a point that Helen wasn't really needed but still came to have a chat and check in on us all, for the brief time we had with Helen she made you feel at ease and you would forget what was actually going on. Mum always loved a laugh about anything and everything, I can't recall at any time that she sat and cried about the situation, the only thing she said was...."oh well, I've had a good life, made lots of friends and memories along the way, what more could I ask for?". We were with mum till the end, she wasn't in any pain which makes it less painful for us. We miss her unbelievably and she has left a massive hole in our hearts

pageSummary: I am climbing Mount Ararat because I want to make a difference
pageSummaryWhy: I want to make a difference
story:
Hello Everyone.

Charity Climb Number 11 involves a trek up and down the snow capped volcano of Ararat, which is the highest point of Turkey and the Armenian Highlands. 

Located in the eastern region, between the Aras and Murat rivers, the name Ararat means ‘Holy Ground’ or ‘Fiery Mountain’ and the summit is considered sacred land, often being described as the final resting place of Noah’s Ark.

With a height of 5,137m (16,854ft)... and a massif ground base of around 22 miles... it is the third most ultra prominent mountain in West Asia and is listed as one of the volcanic seven second summits.

The mountain has great cultural significance and historical importance and will make for a great challenge, taking four days to complete. 

My long standing chosen charity is Macmillan and I am keen to raise much needed funds for this excellent organisation.

For those who would like to support the trek, please click the green ‘Donate’ button to comment and make a contribution directly to the charity. 

Your generosity will help many people to continue battling cancer.

Best Regards, David.

story:
As a fit and healthy person I was shocked when I was diagnosed with bowel cancer totally out of the blue?? Macmillan nurses were with me every step of the way for nearly 2 years. They provided me with emotional and physical support and they gave me hope and encouragement when I felt uncertain of the outcome and the future. Every one of them was kind, caring and understanding making me feel like a member of their family whilst remaining totally professional.

 Having paid my taxes for over 30 years, I was told by DHSS I was not entitled to any benefits but Macmillan nurses fought for me for many months and hooray they got me payment of £17 per week!! 

To me they were my guardian angels to whom I will always be very grateful and I will never forget their kindness.

story: While we're all still in lockdown and the days are cold and short, it's so important we're still getting out and exercising... not just for our hearts and physical health but for our mental wellbeing too! This Heart Month, our team are committing to walk/jog/run 100km (60 miles) and we'd love to get as many people across the community to join in on the challenge too. 100km might sound a lot, but over a month it works out at roughly 2 miles a day - that's roughly a 20min jog, or a 30 minute walk. We're asking everyone who takes part to set a target of £100 and help spread the word. If we get 60 people to join the team, then that's £6,000 raised for the BHF's 60th year to go towards life-saving research. If 2020 taught us anything, it's that research works! The page will be live until the end of March (and, depending on uptake, into April) so if you want to take part in the challenge once the weather warms up, that's totally fine too!

story:
Brief Background


Back in 2017, a team made up of Josh, John and Jane came together to raise a whooping £3000 for the British Heart Foundation by walking 50 miles a day for 5 days. This came after family member suffered with a heart condition that effected the whole family.

4 years on, they're back and joined by Charlie and Dan for another tough challenge!

This Years Challenge - The Six Month Travel

A hard year calls for a hard challenge! Team 'Chafing The Dream' will be walking/running/cycling all across europe (Not Literally!)

Between all five of us, we will be travelling the distance that would be required to travel from one country to another stopping in 7 times with our finishing line being in Estonia.

How Will It Work?

As an example, our first stop is intenting to be Rotterdam. This is 420 miles away from our starting point in the forest of dean. During month one, the team will achive 420 miles between them by either walking/running/cycling. Once that distance has been hit, we will move onto the next country! This will continue untill we hit our finishing line. Of course, if we hit Estonia early, we will contine to travel until our 6 months are up! We will keep everyone updated with regular posts on facebook and keeping track of progess on tracking apps.

during the 6 months, we will be travelling

England, Forest of Dean ---> Netherlands, Rotterdam (420 miles)

Netherlands, Rotterdam ---> Germany, Nuremberg (418 miles)

Germany, Nuremberg ---> Czech Republic, Prague (180 miles)

Czech Republic, Prague ---> Poland, Krakow (390 miles)

Poland, Krakow ---> Lithuania, Kaunas (453 miles)

Lithuania, Kaunas ---> Lativa, Riga (183 miles)

Lativa, Riga ---> Estonia, Narva (291 miles)

We understand that covid has hit many people hard financially, so we have a realistic but big target of £1,200. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit our target. Thanks!

story:
Welcome, welcome! 

Ok, so here we are again trying to raise some awareness and funds for this incredibly worthwhile charity. It's been a few years and luckily this time it's not because someone has died, quite the opposite, it's in order to celebrate lives past and present 😃

My Dad would have been 70 years young this year and in August it will be 5 years since he left us, so it is a great opportunity to do something this year to mark the special occasion. BHF was his chosen charity so that was always on the shortlist to raise money for. Recently however a very best friend of mine suffered a heart attack but is thankfully recovering well at home 👊 A wake up call to us all about taking care of our hearts. So that was it, charity decided upon.

So as the title suggests, I am personally attempting to walk 4000 miles in 2021, or 8 million steps in total. Or to Dubai. It's ok, it only works out at an average of 11 miles, or 22,000 steps every single day. Easy peasy right 🙄😂 This is the underlying challenge that runs throughout the year and to help reach that target there's various special activities planned 😎

In August, a group of us are aiming to walk 70kms (44 miles) to celebrate the 70th birthday. It is going to be over two days, camping overnight, and will be coastal, so it will includes lots of ups and downs and rugged terrain. Fingers crossed my friend in recovery will be fit enough by then to tackle some, if not all of it 😉

There are other things in the pipeline as well. A half marathon is booked up, a 70 miles in a day bike ride planned in and potentially a one, two or three peak challenge taking place .....🤞 but I've blabbered on enough now so might add those details at a later date.

So thanks for your time. By visiting this page, we've raised some awareness for BHF together. If you would like to donate a small amount to charity then please feel free to, in order to support any, or all, of the fundraising activities listed above👍

Best wishes,

Ross (and Team Moobs)

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. I sadly have lost family members to heart attacks and know many other people who have also lost loved ones or have heart problems themselves. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. 

With the possibility of still being in lockdown in March and homeschooling this will be a challenge for me!! Thanks for your support.

story:
My Nan had heart attacks and was fitted with stents and was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  My great grandfather had a heart attack which unfortunately took him from us. He was taken from this world too young. My mother in law also had a heart attack in the last few years. Also my great uncle and auntie are affected with this condition everyday of their lives. I just want to do anything I can to raise awareness of heart conditions. To prevent more families having to go through the devastation it can cause! 

By making small changes to diet and lifestyle can seriously reduce your risk of heart disease as you get older.

 I am de-choxing for March I have chosen March because it’s my birthday month it’s also my nans birthday month. Our birthdays our 6 days apart and we always used to celebrate them together. It’s now been 2 years since she left us. After suffering for years with ATF and crippling arthritis. 

For a person that gave so much and loved so fiercely I want to do this in memory of my Nan and hopefully work towards other ways to raise money for BHF in the future.  

Please donate what you can so that BHF can continue doing the vital work that they do. Working towards a world without heart disease!

story:
I lost my beautiful mum on 5.2.2020 to a heart attack.

She had after being ill for a long time with various health problems, liver failure, TIA (mini stroke) in 2009 just before my wedding, COPD, various allergies, then developing diabetes, muscle weakness and ending up in a wheelchair and then her heart had just given up, luckily both me and my dad were by her side when she passed. 

The funeral was arranged for the friday before the first covid lockdown in March 2020 and due to this lots of people were unable to attend, to give mum the send off she deserved.

Anyone who knows me - knows I love anything sweet, so im going the full way giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy pop for dechox! Please if you can spare anything in these hard times lets raise for BHF.


Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:

Freya loves a lockdown challenge so this time we thought she would do one for a good cause. 

We’ve chose to raise money for cancer research, a charity that’s close to our heart for many reasons. 

Freya will be climbing up and down our local park steps (56 in total) 10 times EVERYDAY for 2 weeks, so in total 7840 which for a 5 year old with little legs is a big task 

As I’m sure a lot of you will know I lost my best friend to cancer she was only 28 and had her whole life ahead of her, she never got to meet Freya but I know she’d be fully behind her challenge and would be cheering her on like the proud auntie she were.

Alone, the fight for cancer cures will never stop, we could all make a huge difference to peoples lives who need it the most.

After the 2nd lockdown challenge I foolishly thought that would be an end to the lockdowns and therefore the challenges would be over..

And yet, here we are in lockdown No 3 so here is the 3rd in the lockdown challenge series!

This lockdown is a little stricter than number 2, with people being urged not to use their cars, so in an attempt to keep folk local I've devised a number of loops throughout Shropshire, which people should be able to pick up wherever they live.
Each loop is between 35 and 40 km in distance, and has a mix of road and off road terrain (so an MTB or gravel bike will be needed).

Every entrant will receive an entry into a prize draw, and I've been very kindly offered prizes of 3 x £10 vouchers and 1 £20 voucher from Shrewsbury based beer store http://www.sophiesbeerstore.co.uk/ these prizes will be randomly drawn from those people on the completed list on 28 February 2021

Here's how to take part:
- To be entered in the draw, complete at least one of the loops below between now and 28 February.
- Donate at least £10 to the JustGiving page (feel free to give more, or even get friends to sponsor you!).
- Email your Strava link or gpx file of your completed ride to phil_sweeney@live.co.uk 
- Every completed ride will be included on the list which anyone can view here (ride more than one loop if you like).
- Covid regulations at the time of completion must be adhered to.
- You can join the loop nearest you at any point, so don't worry about where you start, just make sure you do the complete loop! 
 
The loops:
Shrewsbury loop 41km 808m  Strava
Church Stretton loop 36km 1,005m  Strava
Telford loop 39km 783m  Strava
Ludlow loop 42km 779m  Strava
Oswestry loop 38km 1069m  Strava

Nesscliffe loop 47km 588m  Strava

If you don't have a loop near you and you want to take part, you can either make up your own (35-40 km with as much off-road as you can) or email me and I'll try and devise one for you!

May the weather be with you!

story:
In 2020 the world experienced a lot of life-changing events, from a global pandemic to Australian bushfires which destroyed 47 million acres of land. The bushfires were estimated to have killed more than a billion animals with many still struggling to recover. 

Our forests are home to 80% of the world's terrestrial biodiversity so when they burn, biodiversity burns with it. There are more than 1 million species currently facing extinction if we continue to carry on with life the way we do. 

It's very easy for us to take for granted everything the world has to offer and many of us forget that our natural world, the thing that brings so much wonder, underpins everything we need to survive. The forests, oceans, rivers and soil provide us with the food we eat, the air we breathe and the water we integrate our crops with. Many of us also depend on the great outdoors for our physical and mental health especially so during the pandemic. 

We have all grown up with nature on our doorstep, we are free to explore it whenever we want and as a result, we often take it for granted and exploit it. We overfish our oceans, pollute our rivers, litter our land, clear our forests and build on wetlands. If we continue to do this there will be irreversible impacts on our world, we are already starting to see the impact our choices are having.

The WWF work with governments, businesses, financial institutions and other organisations to try and put nature at the heart of decision making. They want these institutions to recognise the huge impact they're having on our planet and promote sustainable finance, sustainable sourcing, sustainable development and sustainable investing. 

They are also working on various different programmes aimed to help establish green corridors for wildlife, restore major river flows, protect forests and oceans and press for global commitments to end the illegal trade in wildlife. 

In order to help raise awareness of these ongoing issues and raise some money for such an important organisation, we will be running a mile an hour on February 20th. In the time between the runs, we will be aiming to do something environmentally-focused like picking up litter or making healthy, sustainable meals. 

We must make it our priority to protect the world's precious natural resources and fight for our most iconic animals and precious habitats.
